commentBody:
EUPHORIA or UGH? 
No SENIOR CENTERS for me.

I SAID STOP.
So I've stopped.
Thanks, Adrian and Ryan.
CONGRATULATIONS Caitlin! May you and your betrothed have a long lifetime of happiness together and make the world a better place.

Hi Caitlin,
Regarding your wonderment about 12D, I suppose the question mark in [Furniture that's designed to break down?] could mean the constructors or editors were thinking about biodegradable furniture, or portable furniture, but with the S there from the SENIOR CENTER that does not HOST me, I went directly to SECTIONAL without passing Go.

I absolutely loved this one. Gender euphoria? Security blanket? Avengers: Endgame? Yes, yes, and more yes. A lovely start to a wintry weekend across much of the US.

And congratulations, Adrian and Annie, on your engagement!

I found this one tough, and was about to sleep on it, but SECURITYBLANKET and HALLOWEENPARTY suddenly occurred to me and I finished in a rush. Lots of good clues and non-MUNDANE entries made for a fun solve.  I wanted split component to be banana.

I‚Äôm not a member of the KISSARMY because I remember Phil OCHS‚Äôs exhortation and ‚ÄúI ain‚Äôt marching anymore.‚Äù
Crossing two obscure artists seems Naticky.

This one brought me back to the olden days, when I got a corner where nothing was working.  In this case, it was the SE corner.

Like Caitlin, I had BANANA, but I didn't have BEANIE, because I already had THOR and NEE, and also because a BEANIE doesn't wind around the head.  I couldn't come up with TURBAN because it wouldn't come to me that they're wrapped.   

Instead of MUNDANE, I had PROSAIC. I didn't know what property tungsten had, how to end AVENGERS..., HALLOWEEN..., KISS..., SHOW... and ONLINE...

I also had NEAT for [Swell].  For [Roll over], I tried REACT.  

I had no idea what [Knocks the top off of] was, but once I took a chance on SHOWBOATS, MOWS became obvious. Off just the N in HALLOWEEN, I guessed DENSE for the tungsten property, and saw DEN for the winter home.  With the M and the N in place, PROSAIC turned into MUNDANE. By then, I saw TURBAN, and after that, the two  things I didn't actually know for sure came to light:  KISS ARMY and AVENGERS ENDGAME.  Now, HALLOWEEN PARTY and ONLINE CASINOS fell into place.  By that point, TENPIN fell into place on its own.

This was the rare corner where I really had to play around with the answers to finally arrive at the right ones.  But I didn't panic.  I have convinced myself that the NYT cannot throw anything at me that I can't eventually solve*, so I just kept plugging away.  


* I say this because I don't believe in Naticks.  Put another way, I think the editors work hard to make every puzzle solvable.
Can anyone explain 26A.  How does PRACTICE equate to WONT? Thanks

Jan. 25th at 11:59pm is the deadline for voting on THE GRIDDIES, awards for the Times's best puzzles of 2025. We've had pretty good turnout but with the number of critics here in cruciverbia, here's your chance to express yourself! The ballot: https://form.jotform.com/260176984868173 There are 4 categories, with five top puzzles in each category. Vote for ONE in each category, press submit, and you're done. No personal information is required, and anyone can vote. Ryan McCarty has a nomination from last year in this year's ballot, BTW.

Typical Saturday for me where I totally overthunk it and failed miserably. 

Really thought Sia was more contemporary than 2014 so skipped. To my recollection Cousin Itt didn't speak but rather squeaked gibberish so why would you need or pay some like Snoop to voice? Anyway, I didn't get it even though it was so plain to see it.

Lesson learned - go with my gut first then unwind it later as required.

Killer is right. Couldn't get anything but the 60s folk singer and Reese Witherspoon. Had to look up at least 2/3 of the answers.  And even then I didn't know what they were talking about. 
Oh well. On to Monday. Stay safe and warm, y'all.

Love doing crosswords with my mom again, glad she‚Äôs doing better. No way I knew about Phil OCHS, but there‚Äôs no way she‚Äôs heard of YEETED either. We looked it up on UrbanDictionary, and I don‚Äôt think it helped.

Surprised myself! I got through this without lookups and in one of my better times. I've had occasion to be interested in 12A‚ÄîI'm old, so that was my starting point. Next gimme was "Peanuts" at 15A with thoughts of Linus's valued possession. 42A, 48A and 49A started with a lot of easy crosses, and it was just a matter of figuring out how they ended, . 

Really liked some of the misdirection, especially 30A and 42D. MUNDANE would not be used to describe this puzzle.

Thanks, Ryan, and Adrian (and congratulations)!

"I don't have any more decorative tissue for these presents!"
"What a paper-thin excuse."

(And that's a wrap!)

Gender euphoria?  Have I missed something?  I've  felt the euphoria, but it didn't have anything to do with gender, and it always depended on the outcome, especially of haircuts, which frequently made me semi-suicidal. (I started cutting it myself to avoid an early death.)

I was so pleased with myself when I completed the bottom of the puzzle, but it all went away when the top was mostly blank and didn't budge.  I got one from the column that I didn't already have, and it did loosen up some of it, but it didn't last and I was back to slogging.  

It's done now, but what I really could have done without was so many proper names.  Glad I didn't just yeet it, but that might have been because I didn't know the word.

Quite the close one for me tonight.  I really didn't think I'd manage to break the log jam I had at two or three places in the puzzle.   But, a guess here, a stab there, getting rid of a weak answer over there, and it unravelled (or raveled?) in the most beautiful way.

I thought 34D [Pedestrian] was a great example of how my mind often sees only one meaning of the word.  

What's the deal with AVENGERS GAME and 23?  Were there actually 23 movies in a series?  I'm not much of an super hero guy.

It‚Äôs my WONT to love a hard puzzle and, yikes, did I get my wish or what.   There was much gnashing of teeth and regretting of having spent the end to a very long week having another beer at 4am when the puzzle dropped. There was a gluT, er, sorry, HOST of entries I had no idea about, like where I needed about 80 crosses to get AVENGERS ENDGAME (‚ÄúYes, yes, honey, I‚Äôm sure I‚Äôve been in the room when you watched it, and yet I‚Äôve managed to remain blissfully unaware‚Äù) or stubbornly tried to change gimme crosses like AORTA to get GENtle EUPHORIA and an ENtRANT you can plug a Yellowstone geyser vent with. Phil OCHS who? Charlie PUTH who? (Neither has a concert venue under my rock.) And so it went. 

I think I briefly related today to posters who do a drive-by here with a ‚ÄúThis puzzle bites!‚Äù when what they mean to say is, ‚ÄúThis puzzle worked me over.‚Äù

This is a very roundabout way to say congratulations, Adrian and Ryan, on a fine construction with excellent Saturday-worthy clueing. And congratulations on your engagement, Adrian! This marriage thing, by the way, really rocks. 

Happy Saturday, Wordplayers big and small. I‚Äôm off to get some sleep.

Adrian Johnson constructed one the least enjoyable Friday puzzles I have ever attempted to solve (it ran in June 2025). I remembered his name then, and remained prepared to be annoyed by his further creations. Can you imagine my surprise at how much I liked today's grid? I found it very challenging and full of unknowns, yet I managed to deal with it, and in a Friday time of 25 minutes, too (Saturdays usually take me over 30 minutes). My only gripe has to do with the naticky crossing of PUT_ and OC_S. It was my last empty square. I thought it had to be a vowel, but when none of those worked, I gave up and looked up PUTH. I could have done a full alphabet run, but really, looking it up had the same result. I found the misdirection of the clues very clever and yet very gettable, with effort - there is something very cool about feeling your mind open and figure out the riddles that good Saturday clues ultimately are. Much if the fill felt fresh, too. A great puzzle, thanks. Poodle pics time! Here is Lucek growling at some big cats on our smart tv screensaver and enjoying a wintry walk in Warsaw: https://imgur.com/a/2ETOlGi

24D Fan group that often wears black and white face paint 

I was like ‚ÄúThis can‚Äôt possibly be JUGGALOS and I don‚Äôt even know if that‚Äôs spelled right.‚Äù But I put it in any way, just to see it lying there. Of course, nothing crossed. The answer turned out to be KISSARMY.  My answer was better.

Now that was a proper Saturday challenge! I got PERK and LSAT along with ELLE Woods right away. I had rAzoR THIN before I had to change it to PAPER THIN as I knew Charlie PUTH was right. He was popular on the radio on our two week roadtrip when we moved from California to Wisconsin in 2016 and that song had heavy play. https://youtu.be/3AtDnEC4zak?si=AHBYTmpRnr7ot4v- I correctly guessed SECURITY BLANKET and TURBAN! My brother-in-law works in post production as a colorist. He has worked on several of the Marvel films/series and I still didn‚Äôt guess AVENGERS ENDGAME until I had a bunch of crosses ü§¶üèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è I figured out HALLOWEEN but not what followed for a bit. I tried beer before PINT became clear. All in all, I really enjoyed the challenge of this one. Thank you Adrian and Ryan. Congratulations to Adrian and Annie on your engagement! Best wishes for a long and happy life together.

TIL yeeted.

but isnt "chucked" already informal?

Loved this puzzle! The fill felt fresh, and SECURITY BLANKET made me smile :) One of those satisfying Saturdays where i hardly had much on the first pass and then somehow everything fell into place! And with zero look ups for proper nouns... yay!! 

The last square to fall for me was the E in the crossing of ORE and NEE, and was a guess, honestly, since I don't get either answer! Could someone explain why it's NEE and what ORE has to do with national forests?

Congratulations, Adrian, on your engagement.
This was one of my favorite Saturdays in a long time and that seems to be the prevailing sentiment so far.
Lord knows if Andrzej and I both love a puzzle it must be something pretty special.
I thought this was a great challenge for a Saturday, but fair, iwith one sparkling clue after another. I won‚Äôt go over them all since others have. Like others I started from the bottom up and wrangled quite a bit with the NW. Like Andrzej, PUTHS and OCHS were a Natick but I had a vague idea about the H and guessed right. But other than that there was nothing to DEPLORE about this puzzle, it hit all the right notes for me.
I thought crossing two obscure singers with odd names (OCHS and PUTH) was not very cool. Otherwise excellent puzzle, I love the full width answers.

Question for Steve L:

How long did it take you to get 13D [One breaking a 108-year drought in 2016]?
So many things were far from my thought process. I did not enjoy this puzzle but then again some folk don‚Äôt like anchovies like I do. I did persevere and finish but had to settle for a blue star.
Is there a mistake in the clue for 5D? Given the answer it should be ‚Äúquatro minus uno‚Äù not ‚Äúfour minus one‚Äù
Lovely puzzle and beautiful stacks in the top and bottom. The top third was exceptionally challenging to me, but otherwise a good solve.

I may be in the minority but this puzzle fell into place beautifully for me, so I loved it! 

This, despite my betting everything on Quantum of Solace being the 23rd movie in the series (it is 22nd, if you discount Never Say Never Again) because it has the same number of letters as AVENGERSENDGAME. 

TIL that TARE is derived from the same root as ‚Äútarot‚Äù and that TURBAN is etymologically then fraternal twin of ‚Äútulip‚Äù - they both spring from Turkish t√ºlbent "turban, gauze, muslin," and from the Persian dulband "turban" which got its name because the hat looked like the flower. Tulips were introduced to Europe from Central Asia and were the symbol of the later Ottomans. 

Who knew?

I read "Means of closing up a vent" as an actual vent and some mechanism that closes it. But I guess we need to think outside the box. :)

I've heard of the word "yeet" but I'm old and don't use it.

There were so many unusual clues and answers, I thought there was maybe a theme and there just wasn't.

EUROS I knew immediately but didn't enter at first because the answer to "how change comes" would be "in euros" (not that I prefer having a preposition in the answer). Clever clue but it's just not grammatically correct. We had this situation yesterday too. The Times used to be much stricter about these things.

This was not a good puzzle. I did it in 23 minutes (much faster than my average) and still was not happy even a bit. I did not enjoy the random stretches the answers are doing vis-a-vis the clues. Also I think Endgame was the last movie in the saga. But it fit so I wrote that and it was correct. A lot of this happened today. Not happy at all with so many uninteresting entries. We have a had a great week. Some answers were really amazing yesterday and on Thursday. Saturday is a bore.

I found this puzzle quite difficult, and that is a compliment! Out well beyond an hour, but wonderfully satisfying as the many misdirections resolved. And at the end the reward of listening to Phil Ochs songs. Among many others, https://youtu.be/rwXO0sbN4pc?si=WvdhtJwpJuJDuFLw

Sometimes, in fact usually, a solve is a joy, but apart from SECURITY BLANKET which was a lovely revelation, today was a tedious slog for me. Just never felt remotely on the same wavelength as the constructor: like radio vis-√†-vis gamma
Super difficult for me.   Had to cheat and lookup some of the more obscure clues.   Boomer here but I still didn‚Äôt know the protest singer.  Haha.

Phil Ochs - I knew that one immediately.Listen to "Outside of a Close Circle of Friends" (don't know how to do links but easy to find) still a very topical song. Some might know "There But For Fortune".

Some lovely clues with  maybe slightly less well-known words, like MUNDANE, DEPLORES, bevy/HOST, WONT, TURBAN, DISPEL and of course ESCHEWED. A TURBAN is sometimes thought of as just a hat, but there was and is a large community of Sikhs in Leith where I grew up and turbans are a common sight.

I didn't know any of the names except OCHS, so that was frustrating for me, and also some expressions like END RANT, GENDER EUPHORIA, SENIOR CENTERS, SECTIONAL (is this flat-pack furniture?).

Please help with DOGGONE (and Dad blasted!) REC, CUB (sports?)

Pretty difficult!
congratulations on your engagement! construction notes made me cry - puzzle was a tricky one!

You know when you're wearing lots of layers *and* your big fluffy coat and you get an itch right between your shoulder blades?  

Solving this puzzle gave me the feeling I get when I can scratch that itch.

Thank you, Adrian and Ryan, I needed that.

Brilliant misdirection, vague cluing, fresh and fun.  A perfect Saturday offering.

Really liked this one.  A proper Saturday.  Got senior centers; security blanket; and met at almost immediately and thought a new PB was in the offing only to come to a screeching  halt further south.  

Spent too long thinking up the name of the Insane Clown Posse and then couldn‚Äôt come up with their fans‚Äô name, as well as thinking solely of James Bond movies.  

The Oc_s / Put_ intersection was the last square to fall, made far more difficult because I originally had DAGGONE.
The word deplore has nothing to do with regret, but has everything to do with disapproval. I expect cleverness and miss direction, but not an incorrect understanding of words.

This one was interesting, it flowed differently for me than a typical Saturday. Usually I start out with almost nothing and then suddenly it starts flowing. Today I started out quickly and filled in close to half the puzzle, then came to a screeching halt. I got there eventually and ended up a little over my typical Saturday time.
Congratulations Adrian. Being engaged is such a wonderful feeling.

Yes, the Erie were known as the "Cat People." Why? Theories abound--perhaps the bobcat was a totemic animal, or their fierceness in warfare was like unto wildcats, or on account of the raccoon tails they sported on their chapeaux; or perhaps they liked David Bowie*; or . . . Unfortunately, we can't ask the Erie, who were extirpated in the mid17th c. in a genocidal war against the Iroquois. (We imagine the First Nation peoples as all living in harmony with the environment, and each other, when the truth was anything but; and first-contact Europeans were often embroiled into conflicts which had been simmering for centuries.) On old maps of Nouvelle France, Lake Erie is sometimes named Lac du Chat, and the archipelago at the western end--Kelleys and the Bass Islands in Ohio, and Pelee in Ontario--were known as the √éles aux Serpents, from the numerous watersnakes that lived there. Like the Erie, the watersnakes were almost extirpated, down to an estimated population of 1500 in 1999, but through protection, their numbers have increased to 12M+. Bobcats, like most apex predators, have never been numerous, but their population seems to be stable. *https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i1O4iZOt23Q&list=RDi1O4iZOt23Q&start_radio=1
üë®‚Äçüç≥üíã Means of closing up a vent

Adrian Johnson is one of my favourite themeless constructors, and while I‚Äôm not always on the same page as Ryan McCarty, I‚Äôve learned to appreciate and respect his Saturday puzzles. 

This felt like a spiritually pure Saturday puzzle. Challenging, and very satisfying when I got it finished. 

Well done

Lousy puzzle. Most of the misdirects were technically fitting but overly dry. Too much random trivia. Not one shred of satisfaction felt when hitting what should be aha moments.
Saying that this puzzle insists upon itself would be an understatement.
A perfect Saturday knock-down-drag-out!

Oh, lots of digging and scraping, just what my brain hungers for on Saturday.  Answers thrown in that have to be taken out.  Opaque clues.  Grinding hard, even with a grid of answers I‚Äôm mostly familiar with.

And here it was today.  Plenty of forehead wrinkling. Tough, tough, clues, like [Practice] for WONT.  

But also plenty of answers, such as PAPER THIN, ESCHEWED, MUNDANE, and SHOWBOATS, that made me smile and think, ‚ÄúAin‚Äôt English grand?‚Äù  Even an LOL moment, with [It‚Äôll never fly!] for PIG.  

Plus, the sweet memory of my son‚Äôs SECURITY BLANKET, which eventually looked like a lion had used it to sharpen its nails.  

Also, respect. Sheesh ‚Äì this is an uber-low 66-worder fully free of junk!  This is an answer set freshened by 10 NYT debut answers, including the entire bottom three-stack.

Adrian and Ryan, this, your first collab, has been a paradigm Saturday, IMO ‚Äì what a day enhancer!  More please. I. Loved. This.  Thank you!
I can't be the only one who thought the movie was called "Avengers 22: Electric Boogaloo".

A great puzzle is brutally humbling in the first 15 minutes, then like pulling alligator teeth, finally comes to fruition. Funny how clues can make sense in hindsight when at first seeming so clueless.

Not sure which one is my favorite but [It may wind up at the top of one's head](TURBAN) and [It'll never fly!](PIG) are at the top of the long list of top notch clues.  

Must say the inclusion of *up* in [Means of closing up a vent] was a mean 'mis!  

Nicely done and thanks.

Good puzzle. In something very unusual for me, I found myself entering one word of some long, two-word answers, and having to work several minutes to get the other word. Like BLANKET was easy but SECURITY took a while. (Sorry, Linus.) Or I saw AVENGERS right away, but since I don't watch comic book movies it took a bunch of crosses to see ENDGAME. Also, did you know that JUGGALOS has the same number of letters as KISSARMY? It's always good to be reminded of the great Phil OCHS. Still relevant. https://youtu.be/fgrehW44g5s?si=rbZMq1UDy8jGDsdO Thanks!

Not being one good with entertainers‚Äô  names, Phil x Charlie was causing me some ender disphoria. But I guessed right, so: happy now.

A party of bony clues that won me over, the more I chewed.

This one was a challenge for me, 6 mins slower than my Saturday average FWIW.  You know how sometimes a difficult puzzle feels like a tedious slog and you feel irritated and grumpy even after successfully completing it?  This was NOT one of those for me.  I thoroughly enjoyed the cluing, the clever misdirects, and felt a lot of satisfaction when I got the happy music with no lookups.  Getting gold today felt far from certain on the first pass but gradually it all fell into place.  Thumbs up from me!

Wow.
One giant bucket of

...do-not-know-wait-could-it-be-I-think-it-is...yes!

Exhilarating.


*CC lights up a smoke*
Ooooph.

After I changed OREO ARMY to KISS ARMY, I kept wondering if there were Oreo fanatics who are so intense they even paint their faces black and white to look like their favorite cookies. Looking online, I found on Facebook a havanese (dog) named Oreo with 146 followers. The Oreo Army on instagram has one post and 9 followers. This would be the time for a visionary Oreo lover to put out the call and begin recruiting troops.

I'm too old to join and not a big fan of Oreos, but at times like these when our cities are being overrun by thuggish ICE agents, I will gladly join my brothers and sisters in this call to arms full of cookies. We will defeat the forces of fascism and greed, 53 calories and 4.7 grams of sugar at a time!

Children have been drawing comfort from their blankies since the neolithic invention of weaving, but the popularity of the term "security blanket" stems from the character of Linus in Peanuts. Charles Schultz claimed to have coined the term, but that's not true.

Whew. Tough one for me. Ten debut answers and four others that had only appeared once before. And that included the bulk of the longer answers. No big deal - that's just me. Puzzle find - a Sunday from September 8, 1996 by R.H. Wolfe with the title "Plain geometry." Six rebus squares in that one. Here are the answers that included those - with the rebus in parentheses and the crossing down answer just below each one. THE(OVAL)OFFICE (OVAL)TINE (CIRCLE)OFFRIENDS RAN(CIRCLE)SAROUND RUBIKS(CUBE)S (CUBE)ROOT BERMUDA(TRIANGLE) LOVE(TRIANGLE) LAYSONTHE(LINE) WICHITA(LINE)MAN BACKTO(SQUARE)ONE FOUR(SQUARE) Here's that link. https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=9/8/1996&g=28&d=A And I'm done. ...

Really an outstanding Saturday puzzle. So many interesting entries, including actual *words* like DISPEL, SECTIONAL, ESCHEWED and MUNDANE. 

Didn't know PUTH, but did know OCHS---though I'd have guessed H for that crossing in any case.

Solved this one unassisted, but took more than thirty minutes. Did slow myself down a bit by reading "Chucked" as "Chuckled" in 50A.

"Called on one's birthday?" for NEE was one of my favorites here. Simple and yet so clever.

As is my WONT on a chilly Saturday morning, I will tell you about my experience solving this puzzle. It was a fine, tricky puzzle, with fresh fill, clever misdirects, and slow and steady progress, until I ran into the wall in the West! [It'll never fly!] There are lots of things that can't fly! And surely the "contents of a stein" has got to be bIer, even though it conflicts with a few things I'm fairly sure of. ENDRANT? GENDER EUPHORIA? Don't get me started. Well, I got through it, but it was work. But work is good, and I'll never (never?) complain about a puzzle being too tricky. As for PIGs, I assume that our constructors and editors are unfamiliar with the famous flying PIGs of Cincinnati. https://www.flickr.com/photos/10707024@N04/albums/72157633413896044/ And a final note to Adrian: I'm impressed with your confidence, and I surely hope your beloved said "Yes," and not "I SAID STOP!!!" Congratulations!
Adrian, I hope she said yes and congrats if so! (If not, this is all awkward.)

Lovely Saturday puzzle. Good fun. But I do have one minor quibble: that pints are supposedly served in steins. I would never bring the two together! Perhaps I've lived with the metric system too long but a stein usually refers to the German "Bierkrug", or "Masskrug" - the ones you see at the Oktoberfest or in the beer garden. A "Mass" refers to a full liter, and a "Halbe" to 500 ml - close to a pint, but not quite. Plus culturally speaking, when I think of a pint (U.S. or imperial), I picture a nice conical glass, or one with a comfy bulge at the top. All are wonderful ways to experience a brewed beverage, but so very different. 

END RANT. 

And now I'm thirsty. Prost everybody!
My mileage varied on this one.  :-/  However, I‚Äôm still mightily impressed with the skill it takes to construct these things!
Tough for me.  But got it in the end.  I probably should not have done it when I was exhausted.

I also had to work this one from the bottom up! And I can't let the opportunity go by to plug my favorite Phil OCHS song (about the submarine Thresher) that sends shivers up my spine every time I listen to it: https://youtu.be/zClEHMU8W_4?si=nSNhwUJdyZv-KLmY

Aside from my suspicion that some of us have been purposely  (or perhaps unintentionally) insulted, I am annoyed to have spent a huge amount of time on this puzzle when I have a giant SNAFU to correct.  You might say my patience has been worn PAPER THIN.  Right at this moment, the best thing I can say in praise of this puzzle is this:  at least the answer to 19A's "Afghans, e.g." was not QUILTS.  
Lewis will no doubt find praise-worthy words, as is his WONT.

That was not in my wave length but it seemed like it would be a good puzzle for others. 

I would say it was like eel sushi. If you don‚Äôt know what it is you like it. Or tripe. And if you put enough ketchup on either, it‚Äôs like eating soggy French fries. 

So yeah it was like eating soggy French fries.
hahaha you shoulda seen *how* confidently i put in "banana" for 37D

Now THAT was a workout! My grid was distressingly blank for a long time. I kept chipping and chipping and it finally started to click. Thanks for the challenge, and congratulations to Adrian and Anne on your engagement!
You lost me at ENDRANT.
I really thought my streak was over. That was exhausting.
a 23-film series? I thought it had to be the Scooby Doo franchise, but I guess there are others just as repetitive...
This was a thoroughly unenjoyable slog.

I thought I was doing well until...

I was sure the crossing OCHS + PUTH and/or ENDRANT + WONT was where my problem was, but couldn't pull it off without my first trip to that answer key in about 3 weeks.

I mean, it is a Saturday puzzle.

Well I guess I shouldn‚Äôt have had that extra glass of wine last night. I fell asleep solving at 10pm, 2:30am and again at 5am. Not because I was in a drunken stupor. Rather, I struggled mightily through most of the grid and thought I might not finish. But I got there at last with a 5-minute push at 6:15. Fist pump! Despite a very sad solve time, I loved the puzzle. A proper Saturday IMO. Thanks Adrien & Ryan. And congratulations to Adrien! I hope the answer was yes!

Escaped doing research by the skin of my teeth. Or the skin of something. This was emotional.

Taking out 'banana' and changing wOWS to MOWS finally blasted open that corner and I thought I was done. But nay. Got the dreaded lack of music. When my flyspecking hit OCHS + PUTH, I pulled up short. Never heard of PUTH. All of those crosses had to be what they were, didn't they? Skinned my fingertips holding on at this point, barely resisted checking that spelling. Took advantage of the online feature that lets you know when you are done--I know you purists don't do that, but my philosophy is to go with whatever is least objectionable in my personal cheat rules, and really, if they hadn't wanted us to use this feature, they wouldn't have included it, would they?--by running the alphabet on the first and last letters of his name. But either it was correct or I had more than one error. I really, really wanted to check that spelling.

Instead, continued fly specking and realized I probably don't know how to spell YEaTED after all. Reconsidering that got the win. 

My fingernails are barely intact.

And now, well satisfied, I'm going to go for another cup of coffee. Maybe some chocolate. And if any of you thought this was too easy, I don't want to hear about it.

My personal Natick was ENDRANT/ANA - I was thinking of the physical vent, and thought maybe it was a ring or something. I slept on it after finishing and not getting the happy music, and this morning finally realized the tennis player's name didn't have to be Ina. With the A in place and a bit of caffeine END RANT occurred to me. Until the comments I thought it was a dumb answer, something the constructor made up, but I guess it's a real thing. I've been trying to stay away from social media, especially the kind where people are venting.
END RANT
I really loved this one! a tough one to crack but once I got AVENGERS ENDGAME everything fell into place.

After reading the explosion of comments about the euphoria of new clothes and haircut, I see that I did, indeed, miss something.  I didn't see the clue as relating to anything about gender.I never think about gender differences when I put on a new outfit.  I don't identify my friends by gender or think, He's gay and she's not when I see them in new clothes, but I see now what joy it must be to slide into the identity your were born with, instead of one that was "assigned" by the physical attributes of your body.  

The tension and hostility toward people of different sexual identities and self image are yet another artificial barrier meant to divide us into the deserving and the undeserving, meant to claim superiority and power.  It would be pathetic if it weren't so brutal and damaging.

I see now that my missing a gender connection completely when I saw the solve is both my lack and my blessing.

Because in my mind, in my experience, those two things don't fit together. However, when beer and glass and meant for each other, that is a thing of joy. Listen, I'm a woman who got emotional when I was served a Bavarian Weissbier in the correct glass at the wonderful Novare Res in Portland, Maine. Really, I cried. Because, for me, it was a sign of respect, of understanding, and of knowing where the product came from, and celebrating it with the perfect exterior.

Phil Ochs. What can be said about a true cultural icon who took his own sorry life at 35:
"His mental health problems included depression, bipolar disorder, and alcoholism. He died by suicide on April 9, 1976."
"Ochs's drinking became more and more of a problem, and his behavior became increasingly erratic. He frightened his friends both with his drunken rants about the FBI and CIA."
"Ochs went to Chile, where Salvador Allende, a Marxist, had been democratically elected in the 1970 election."
"In mid-1975, Ochs took on the identity of John Butler Train. He told people that Train had murdered Ochs and that he, John Butler Train, had replaced him. Ochs was convinced that someone was trying to kill him, so he carried a weapon at all times: a hammer, a knife, or a lead pipe." (At least he didn't get hold of a firearm).
"His brother, Michael, attempted to have him committed to a psychiatric hospital. Friends pleaded with him to get help voluntarily. They feared for his safety because he was getting into fights with bar patrons. Unable to pay his rent, he began living on the streets."
"After several months, the Train persona faded and Ochs returned, but his talk of suicide disturbed his friends and family. They hoped it was a passing phase, but Ochs was determined."
Yep, that's a true American hero that needs to be lauded, embraced and celebrated.

Reposting your Tuesday‚Äôs notes on The Magic Mountain below with some of my thoughts (after asterisks):

1. Mann uses the word ‚Äúeinfachen‚Äù.  Dictionaries give simple, uncomplicated, and straight forward.  Translators give ‚Äúsimple-minded‚Äù [L-P] and ‚Äúperfectly ordinary‚Äù [Woods].  I will argue that his character in constrained by this place and time, but that he is in no way an ordinary man.  *** I‚Äôll leave my uniqueness counterargument until you‚Äôve finished the book. (I don‚Äôt know how much you‚Äôll be influenced by  L-P‚Äôs ‚Äôs translation. It‚Äôs been written, perhaps unkindly, that she hadn‚Äôt read the entire novel before beginning to translate it. I know that her translation of Death in Venice mis-portrays a key character in a way that changes the psychological thrust of the book.) I‚Äôll say this: Keep an eye out for narrative feints. 

2.  The Castorps are not aristocrats.  They have been of the merchant class since 1650, the first date etched on the family Christening Basin.  The six generations listed there have survived despite momentous changes in the outside world.  (The end of the 30 years war, the rise of Prussia under Frederick the Great, and the unification of Germany under Bismark).  Hamburg has remained a self-governing city-state.  His grandfather was a Senator in the local council. 

Continued below.

‚Ä¶ continued. 

*** Yes, they‚Äôre the perfect specimens of the German Bildungsb√ºrgertum, the educated bourgeoisie. It‚Äôs important to keep in mind what history has laid at the Bildungsb√ºrgertum‚Äôs door following the 18th c. and WWI (remember that Mann published the book after WWI), and later again in the wake of WWII. 

3. I would describe Hans' character as constrained by middle-class morality and manners. 4-6 show . . . H's uniqueness. ***. 3. The morality of the Bildungsb√ºrgertum was very aesthetically mediated. Manners  were key. Hans is a decent man, but can his decency make him dangerous? It makes him maximally receptive, but does it make him decisive? 

4.  He is an orphan.  He has lost mother, father, and guardian grandfather within the two and a half years before the age of eight.  We are told little of his education other than eight semesters at technical colleges ending at age 22.  He has ‚Äúnever met a literary man".  (I will find more when  I get to later chapters.  Spoiler: I've heard that the first appearance of ‚Äúthe pencil‚Äù will occur while he is away at boarding school.)  *** A lack of a humanistic education may make a young person morally bland, don‚Äôt you think? Still a blank slate, impressionable? As an orphan, by whom is his character being shaped? Mann doesn‚Äôt present Hans‚Äôs orphanhood as individuating, but functional. It frees him from binding obligations, removes inherited ideological commitments, makes him available for influence.

part 3:

He‚Äôs not psychologically scarred; he‚Äôs unencumbered. He has money, a technical education, social legitimacy, no urgent attachments. He embodies the rootless, late-imperial bourgeois subject. 

5. Some personal quirks:  He is angered by the slamming of doors and scandalized by the ‚Äúactivities‚Äù of the couple in the next room.  He says things like ‚ÄúI really like the sight of a coffin.‚Äù and ‚ÄúFunerals are more uplifting than church.‚Äù *** These might be quirks today, but were they in pre-WWI Germany? He has an aversion to orderliness disrupted by noise or, as we‚Äôd say, TMI. And death, like other experiences, is mediated aesthetically in a culture that has removed itself from its immediacy. Think of Hans‚Äôs first aestheticized encounter with death, his grandfather‚Äôs: He experiences it as beautiful form (ritual, objects, atmosphere), not rupture or grief; something he can contemplate without cost. He is not morbid; he‚Äôs a product of his time and place. 

6. Whether the door slammed by Mme. Chauchat (hot cat) is a Freudian symbol of sexual rejection remains to be seen. *** What if Hans stands for the West in the 1910s and Chauchat for the East? Not the Far East but the one represented at the time by Russia. You could read the ‚Äúhot cat‚Äù as the allure of the exotic, forbidden East for Mann‚Äôs and Castorp‚Äôs West, with the East slamming its doors (loudly) in the face of the curious (and culturally restrained) West, remaining opaque behind the veil of a language Hans doesn‚Äôt speak.

@Bill you may have caught me in a half-truth because I can only find Tarot etymologies (in English and French) that point to a *possible* derivation from the same Arabic word that is the ancestor of tare. For example, here are two citations from Etymoline:

tare(n.2)
in commerce, "allowable difference between gross and net weight, deduction made from gross weight of goods to account for approximate weight of packaging or container holding them," late 15c., from Anglo-French tare "wastage in goods, deficiency, imperfection" (late 14c.), from Italian tara, Medieval Latin tara, from Arabic tarah, literally "thing deducted or rejected, that which is thrown away," from taraha "to reject."

tarot(n.)
1590s, from French tarot (16c.), from Old Italian tarocchi (singular tarocco), a word of unknown origin, perhaps from Arabic taraha "he rejected, put aside."
@Bill "Tare" is definitely from Arabic "taraha" (to reject). There's about a 50-50 chance that "tarot" is from the same Arabic root (the other possibility is from an old Italian word meaning "fool.")

Acknowledging a person's right to self-presentation seems consistent with many other rights that we're used to. So why does this one rile us up do?
I think in part this relates to how deeply we value sexuality. Sex is literally the most profound impulse we have. Every society I've ever heard of has taboos around sexuality. Playing around with it is destabilizing in many ways. It's  just too scary for many of us if we can't clearly and immediately identify someone's gender.
